member.name: T:Assimp.Animation
member.summary: An animation consists of keyframe data for a number of nodes. For each node affected by the animation, a separate series of data is given.

member.name: P:Assimp.Animation.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the animation. If the modeling package the data was exported from only supports a single animation channel, this name is usually empty.

member.name: P:Assimp.Animation.DurationInTicks
member.summary: Gets or sets the duration of the animation in number of ticks.

member.name: P:Assimp.Animation.TicksPerSecond
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of ticks per second. It may be zero if it is not specified in the imported file.

member.name: T:Assimp.AssimpContext
member.summary: Represents an Assimp Import/Export context that load or save models using the unmanaged library. Additionally, conversion functionality is offered to bypass loading model data into managed memory.

member.name: P:Assimp.AssimpContext.IsDisposed
member.summary: Gets if the context has been disposed.

member.name: P:Assimp.AssimpContext.Scale
member.summary: Gets or sets the uniform scale for the model. This is multiplied with the existing root node's transform. This is only used during import.

member.name: P:Assimp.AssimpContext.XAxisRotation
member.summary: Gets or sets the model's rotation about the X-Axis, in degrees. This is multiplied with the existing root node's transform. This is only used during import.

member.name: P:Assimp.AssimpContext.YAxisRotation
member.summary: Gets or sets the model's rotation abut the Y-Axis, in degrees. This is multiplied with the existing root node's transform. This is only used during import.

member.name: P:Assimp.AssimpContext.ZAxisRotation
member.summary: Gets or sets the model's rotation about the Z-Axis, in degrees. This is multiplied with the existing root node's transform. This is only used during import.

member.name: P:Assimp.AssimpContext.UsingCustomIOSystem
member.summary: Gets whether this context is using a user-defined IO system for file handling.

member.name: P:Assimp.AssimpContext.PropertyConfigurations
member.summary: Gets the property configurations set to this context. This is only used during import.

member.name: M:Assimp.AssimpContext.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Assimp.AssimpContext.ImportFileFromStream(System.IO.Stream,System.String)
member.summary: Imports a model from the stream without running any post-process steps. The importer sets configurations and loads the model into managed memory, releasing the unmanaged memory used by Assimp. It is up to the caller to dispose of the stream. If the format is distributed across multiple files/streams, set a custom and use the "ImportFile" family of functions.
member.param: Optional format extension to serve as a hint to Assimp to choose which importer to use. If null or empty, the system will try to detect what importer to use from the data which may or may not be successful.
member.returns: The imported scene
member.exception: Thrown if the stream is not valid (null or write-only).
Thrown if the context has already been disposed of.

member.name: M:Assimp.AssimpContext.ImportFileFromStream(System.IO.Stream,Assimp.PostProcessSteps,System.String)
member.summary: Imports a model from the stream. The importer sets configurations and loads the model into managed memory, releasing the unmanaged memory used by Assimp. It is up to the caller to dispose of the stream. If the format is distributed across multiple files/streams, set a custom and use the "ImportFile" family of functions.
member.param: Optional format extension to serve as a hint to Assimp to choose which importer to use. If null or empty, the system will try to detect what importer to use from the data which may or may not be successful.
member.returns: The imported scene
member.exception: Thrown if the stream is not valid (null or write-only).
Thrown if the context has already been disposed of.

member.name: M:Assimp.AssimpContext.ImportFile(System.String)
member.summary: Imports a model from the specified file without running any post-process steps. The importer sets configurations and loads the model into managed memory, releasing the unmanaged memory used by Assimp.
member.returns: The imported scene
member.exception: Thrown if there was a general error in importing the model.
Thrown if the file could not be located.
Thrown if the context has already been disposed of.

member.name: M:Assimp.AssimpContext.ImportFile(System.String,Assimp.PostProcessSteps)
member.summary: Imports a model from the specified file. The importer sets configurations and loads the model into managed memory, releasing the unmanaged memory used by Assimp.
member.returns: The imported scene
member.exception: Thrown if there was a general error in importing the model.
Thrown if the file could not be located.
Thrown if the context has already been disposed of.

member.name: M:Assimp.AssimpContext.ExportFile(Assimp.Scene,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Exports a scene to the specified format and writes it to a file.
member.param: Scene containing the model to export.
FormatID representing the format to export to.
member.returns: True if the scene was exported successfully, false otherwise.
member.exception: Thrown if the scene is null.
Thrown if the context has already been disposed of.

member.name: M:Assimp.AssimpContext.ExportFile(Assimp.Scene,System.String,System.String,Assimp.PostProcessSteps)
member.summary: Exports a scene to the specified format and writes it to a file.

FormatID representing the format to export to.
Preprocessing flags to apply to the model before it is exported.
member.returns: True if the scene was exported successfully, false otherwise.
member.exception: Thrown if the scene is null.
Thrown if the context has already been disposed of.

member.summary: Exports a scene to the specified format and writes it to a data blob.

FormatID representing the format to export to.
member.returns: The resulting data blob, or null if the export failed.
member.exception: Thrown if the scene is null.
Thrown if the context has already been disposed of.

member.summary: Exports a scene to the specified format and writes it to a data blob.

FormatID representing the format to export to.
Preprocessing flags to apply to the model before it is exported.

member.name: M:Assimp.AssimpContext.ConvertFromFileToFile(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Converts the model contained in the file to the specified format and save it to a file.
member.param: Output file name to export to
Format id that specifies what format to export to
member.returns: True if the conversion was successful or not, false otherwise.
member.exception: Thrown if there was a general error in importing the model.

member.name: T:Assimp.Bone
member.summary: Represents a single bone of a mesh. A bone has a name which allows it to be found in the frame hierarchy and by which it can be addressed by animations. In addition it has a number of influences on vertices and a matrix relating the mesh position to the position of the bone at the time of binding.

member.name: P:Assimp.Bone.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the bone.

member.name: P:Assimp.Bone.VertexWeightCount
member.summary: Gets the number of vertex influences the bone contains.

member.name: P:Assimp.Bone.HasVertexWeights
member.summary: Gets if the bone has vertex weights - this should always be true.

member.name: P:Assimp.Bone.VertexWeights
member.summary: Gets the influence weights of this bone, by vertex index.

member.name: P:Assimp.Bone.OffsetMatrix
member.summary:
Gets or sets the matrix that transforms from bone space to mesh space in bind pose. This matrix describes the position of the mesh in the local space of this bone when the skeleton was bound. Thus it can be used directly to determine a desired vertex position, given the world-space transform of the bone when animated, and the position of the vertex in mesh space.
It is sometimes called an inverse-bind matrix or inverse-bind pose matrix.

member.name: M:Assimp.Bone.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Constructs a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:Assimp.Camera
member.summary: Describes a right-handed camera in the scene. An important aspect is that the camera itself is also part of the scenegraph, meaning any values such as the direction vector are not *absolute*, they can be relative to the coordinate system defined by the node which corresponds to the camera. This allows for camera animations.

member.name: P:Assimp.Camera.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the camera. This corresponds to a node in the scenegraph with the same name. This node specifies the position of the camera in the scene hierarchy and can be animated.

member.name: P:Assimp.Camera.Position
member.summary: Gets or sets the position of the camera relative to the coordinate space defined by the corresponding node. THe default value is 0|0|0.

member.name: P:Assimp.Camera.Up
member.summary: Gets or sets the 'up' vector of the camera, relative to the coordinate space defined by the corresponding node. The 'right' vector of the camera is the cross product of the up and direction vectors. The default value is 0|1|0.

member.name: P:Assimp.Camera.Direction
member.summary: Gets or sets the viewing direction of the camera, relative to the coordinate space defined by the corresponding node. The default value is 0|0|1.

member.name: P:Assimp.Camera.FieldOfview
member.summary: Gets or sets the half horizontal field of view angle, in radians. The FoV angle is the angle between the center line of the screen and the left or right border. The default value is 1/4PI.

member.name: P:Assimp.Camera.ClipPlaneNear
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance of the near clipping plane from the camera. The value may not be 0.0f for arithmetic reasons to prevent a division through zero. The default value is 0.1f;

member.name: P:Assimp.Camera.ClipPlaneFar
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance of the far clipping plane from the camera. The far clippling plane must be further than the near clippling plane. The default value is 1000.0f. The ratio between the near and far plane should not be too large (between 1000 - 10000 should be ok) to avoid floating-point inaccuracies which can lead to z-fighting.

member.name: P:Assimp.Camera.AspectRatio
member.summary: Gets or sets the screen aspect ratio. This is the ratio between the width and height of the screen. Typical values are 4/3, 1/2, or 1/1. This value is 0 if the aspect ratio is not defined in the source file. The default value is zero.

member.name: P:Assimp.Camera.ViewMatrix
member.summary: Gets a right-handed view matrix.

member.name: M:Assimp.Camera.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Gets if the native value type is blittable (that is, does not require marshaling by the runtime, e.g. has MarshalAs attributes).

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.MultithreadingConfig
member.summary: Configuration to set Assimp's multithreading policy. Possible values are -1 to let Assimp decide, 0 to disable multithreading, or any number larger than zero to force a specific number of threads. This is only a hint and may be ignored by Assimp. Default value is -1.

member.summary: Gets the string name used by MultithreadingConfig.

member.summary: Constructs a new MultithreadingConfig.
member.param: A value of -1 will let Assimp decide, a value of zero to disable multithreading, and a value greater than zero to force a specific number of threads.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.NoSkeletonMeshesConfig
member.summary: Global setting to disable generation of skeleton dummy meshes. These are generated as a visualization aid in cases which the input data contains no geometry, but only animation data. So the geometry are visualizing the bones. Default value is false.

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.NoSkeletonMeshesConfig.NoSkeletonMeshesConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by NoSkeletonMeshConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.NoSkeletonMeshesConfig.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a new NoSkeletonMeshConfig.
member.param: True if dummy skeleton mesh generation should be disabled, false otherwise.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.TangentSmoothingAngleConfig
member.summary: Configuration to set the maximum angle that may be between two vertex tangents/bitangents when they are smoothed during the step to calculate the tangent basis. The default value is 45 degrees.

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.TangentSmoothingAngleConfig.TangentSmoothingAngleConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by TangentSmoothingAngleConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.TangentSmoothingAngleConfig.#ctor(System.Single)
member.summary: Constructs a new TangentSmoothingAngleConfig.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.NormalSmoothingAngleConfig
member.summary: Configuration to set the maximum angle between two face normals at a vertex when they are smoothed during the step to calculate smooth normals. This is frequently called the "crease angle". The maximum and default value is 175 degrees.

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.NormalSmoothingAngleConfig.NormalSmoothingAngleConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by NormalSmoothingAngleConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.NormalSmoothingAngleConfig.#ctor(System.Single)
member.summary: Constructs a new NormalSmoothingAngleConfig.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.MDLColorMapConfig
member.summary: Configuration to set the colormap (palette) to be used to decode embedded textures in MDL (Quake or 3DG5) files. This must be a valid path to a file. The file is 768 (256 * 3) bytes alrge and contains RGB triplets for each of the 256 palette entries. If the file is not found, a default palette (from Quake 1) is used. The default value is "colormap.lmp".

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.MDLColorMapConfig.MDLColorMapConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by MDLColorMapConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.MDLColorMapConfig.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs a new MDLColorMapConfig.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.MaterialExcludeListConfig
member.summary: Configuration for the the step to determine what materials to keep. If a material matches one of these names it will not be modified or removed by the post processing step. Default is an empty string.

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.MaterialExcludeListConfig.MaterialExcludeListConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by MaterialExcludeListConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.MaterialExcludeListConfig.#ctor(System.String[])
member.summary: Constructs a new MaterialExcludeListConfig. Material names containing whitespace must be enclosed in single quotation marks.
member.param: List of material names that will not be modified or replaced by the remove redundant materials post process step.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.KeepSceneHierarchyConfig
member.summary: Configuration for the step to keep the scene hierarchy. Meshes are moved to worldspace, but no optimization is performed where meshes with the same materials are not joined. This option can be useful if you have a scene hierarchy that contains important additional information which you intend to parse. The default value is false.

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.KeepSceneHierarchyConfig.KeepSceneHierarchyConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by KeepSceneHierarchyConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.KeepSceneHierarchyConfig.#ctor(System.Boolean)

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.TerragenComputeTexCoordsConfig
member.summary:
Configures the terragen import plugin to compute UV's for terrains, if they are not given. Furthermore, a default texture is assigned. The default value is false.
UV coordinates for terrains are so simple to compute that you'll usually want to compute them on your own, if you need them. This option is intended for model viewers which want to offer an easy way to apply textures to terrains.

member.summary: Tells the MD3 loader which skin files to load. When loading MD3 files, Assimp checks whether a file named "md3_file_name"_"skin_name".skin exists. member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.LWOImportOneLayerConfig
member.summary:
Configures the LWO loader to load just one layer from the model.
LWO files consist of layers and in some cases it could be useful to load only one of them. This property can be either a string - which specifies the name of the layer - or an integer - the index of the layer. If the property is not set then the whole LWO model is loaded. Loading fails if the requested layer is not vailable. The layer index is zero-based and the layer name may not be empty The default value is false (all layers are loaded).

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.LWOImportOneLayerConfig.LWOImportOneLayerConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by LWOImportOneLayerConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.LWOImportOneLayerConfig.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a new LWOImportOneLayerConfig.
member.param: True if only one layer should be imported, false if all layers should be imported.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.MD5NoAnimationAutoLoadConfig
member.summary:
Configures the MD5 loader to not load the MD5ANIM file for a MD5MESH file automatically. The default value is false.
The default strategy is to look for a file with the same name but with the MD5ANIm extension in the same directory. If it is found it is loaded and combined with the MD5MESH file. This configuration option can be used to disable this behavior.

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.MD5NoAnimationAutoLoadConfig.MD5NoAnimationAutoLoadConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by MD5NoAnimationAutoLoadConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.MD5NoAnimationAutoLoadConfig.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a new MD5NoAnimationAutoLoadConfig.
member.param: True if animations should not be automatically loaded, false if they should be.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.LWSAnimationStartConfig
member.summary:
Defines the beginning of the time range for which the LWS loader evaluates animations and computes AiNodeAnim's. The default value is the one taken from the file.
Assimp provides full conversion of Lightwave's envelope system, including pre and post conditions. The loader computes linearly subsampled animation channels with the frame rate given in the LWS file. This property defines the start time.
Animation channels are only generated if a node has at least one envelope with more than one key assigned. This property is given in frames where '0' is the first. By default, if this property is not set, the importer takes the animation start from the input LWS file ('FirstFrame' line)

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.LWSAnimationStartConfig.LWSAnimationStartConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by LWSAnimationStartConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.LWSAnimationStartConfig.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a new LWSAnimationStartConfig.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.LWSAnimationEndConfig
member.summary:
Defines the ending of the time range for which the LWS loader evaluates animations and computes AiNodeAnim's. The default value is the one taken from the file
Assimp provides full conversion of Lightwave's envelope system, including pre and post conditions. The loader computes linearly subsampled animation channels with the frame rate given in the LWS file. This property defines the end time.
Animation channels are only generated if a node has at least one envelope with more than one key assigned. This property is given in frames where '0' is the first. By default, if this property is not set, the importer takes the animation end from the input LWS file.

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.LWSAnimationEndConfig.LWSAnimationEndConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by LWSAnimationEndConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.LWSAnimationEndConfig.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a new LWSAnimationEndConfig.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.IRRAnimationFrameRateConfig
member.summary:
Defines the output frame rate of the IRR loader.
IRR animations are difficult to convert for Assimp and there will always be a loss of quality. This setting defines how many keys per second are returned by the converter. The default value is 100 frames per second.

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.IRRAnimationFrameRateConfig.IRRAnimationFrameRateConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by IRRAnimationFrameRateConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.IRRAnimationFrameRateConfig.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a new IRRAnimationFramerateConfig.
member.param: Number of frames per second to output.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.OgreMaterialFileConfig
member.summary: The Ogre importer will try to load this MaterialFile. Ogre meshes reference with material names, this does not tell Assimp where the file is located. Assimp will try to find the source file in the following order: [material-name].material, [mesh-filename-base].material, and lastly the material name defined by this config property. The default value is "Scene.Material".

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.OgreMaterialFileConfig.OgreMaterialFileConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by OgreMaterialFileConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.OgreMaterialFileConfig.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs a new OgreMaterialFileConfig.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.OgreTextureTypeFromFilenameConfig
member.summary:
The Ogre importer will detect the texture usage from the filename. Normally a texture is loaded as a color map, if no target is specified in the material file. If this is enabled, then Assimp will try to detect the type from the texture filename postfix:
Normal Maps: _n, _nrm, _nrml, _normal, _normals, _normalmap
Specular Maps: _s, _spec, _specular, _specularmap
Light Maps: _l, _light, _lightmap, _occ, _occlusion
Displacement Maps: _dis, _displacement
The matching is case insensitive. Postfix is taken between the last "_" and last ".". The default behavior is to detect type from lower cased texture unit name by matching against: normalmap, specularmap, lightmap, and displacementmap. For both cases if no match is found then, is used. The default value is false.

member.name: P:Assimp.Configs.OgreTextureTypeFromFilenameConfig.OgreTextureTypeFromFilenameConfigName
member.summary: Gets the string name used by OgreTextureTypeFromFilenameConfig.

member.name: M:Assimp.Configs.OgreTextureTypeFromFilenameConfig.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a new OgreTextureTypeFromFilenameConfig.
member.param: True if the filename defines texture usage, false otherwise.

member.name: T:Assimp.Configs.IFCUseCustomTriangulationConfig
member.summary: Specifies whether the IFC loader will use its own, custom triangulation algorithm to triangulate wall and floor meshes. If this is set to false, walls will be either triangulated by the post process triangulation or will be passed through as huge polygons with faked holes (e.g. holes that are connected with the outer boundary using a dummy edge). It is highly recommended to leave this property set to true as the default post process has some known issues with these kind of polygons.

member.name: T:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture
member.summary: Represents an embedded texture. Some file formats directly embed texture assets. Embedded textures may be uncompressed, where the data is given in an uncompressed format. Or it may be compressed in a format like png or jpg. In the latter case, the raw file bytes are given so the application must utilize an image decoder (e.g. DevIL) to get access to the actual color data. This object represents both types, so some properties may or may not be valid depending if it is compressed or not.

member.name: P:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture.Filename
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture's original filename.

member.name: P:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture.IsCompressed
member.summary: Gets if the texture is compressed or not.

member.name: P:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture.Width
member.summary: Gets the width of the texture in pixels. Only valid for non-compressed textures.

member.name: P:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture.Height
member.summary: Gets the height of the texture in pixels. Only valid for non-compressed textures.

member.name: P:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture.HasNonCompressedData
member.summary: Gets if the texture has non-compressed texel data. Only valid for non-compressed textures.

member.name: P:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture.NonCompressedDataSize
member.summary: Gets the size of the non-compressed texel data. Only valid for non-compressed textures.

member.name: P:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture.NonCompressedData
member.summary: Gets the non-compressed texel data, the array is of size Width * Height. Only valid for non-compressed textures.

member.name: P:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture.HasCompressedData
member.summary: Gets if the embedded texture has compressed data. Only valid for compressed textures.

member.name: P:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture.CompressedDataSize
member.summary: Gets the size of the compressed data. Only valid for compressed textures.

member.name: P:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture.CompressedData
member.summary: Gets the raw byte data representing the compressed texture. Only valid for compressed textures.

member.name: P:Assimp.EmbeddedTexture.CompressedFormatHint
member.summary: Gets the format hint to determine the type of compressed data. This hint is a three-character lower-case hint like "dds", "jpg", "png".

member.name: T:Assimp.PostProcessSteps
member.summary: Post processing flag options, specifying a number of steps that can be run on the data to either generate additional vertex data or optimize the imported data.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.None
member.summary: No flags enabled.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.CalculateTangentSpace
member.summary:
Calculates the tangents and binormals (bitangents) for the imported meshes.
This does nothing if a mesh does not have normals. You might want this post processing step to be executed if you plan to use tangent space calculations such as normal mapping. There is a config setting AI_CONFIG_PP_CT_MAX_SMOOTHING_ANGLE which allows you to specify a maximimum smoothing angle for the algorithm. However, usually you'll want to leave it at the default value.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.JoinIdenticalVertices
member.summary:
Identifies and joins identical vertex data sets within all imported meshes.
After this step is run, each mesh contains unique vertices, so a vertex may be used by multiple faces. You usually want to use this post processing step. If your application deals with indexed geometry, this step is compulsory or you'll just waste rendering time.
If this flag is not specified, no vertices are referenced by more than one face and no index buffer is required for rendering.
Unless the importer (like ply) had to split vertices. Then you need one regardless.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.MakeLeftHanded
member.summary:
Converts all imported data to a left handed coordinate space.
By default the data is returned in a right-handed coordinate space, where +X points to the right, +Z towards the viewer, and +Y upwards.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.Triangulate
member.summary:
Triangulates all faces of all meshes.
By default the imported mesh data might contain faces with more than three indices. For rendering you'll usually want all faces to be triangles. This post processing step splits up all higher faces to triangles. Line and point primitives are *not* modified. If you want 'triangles only' with no other kinds of primitives, try the following:
Specify both and .
Ignore all point and line meshes when you process Assimp's output

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.RemoveComponent
member.summary:
Removes some parts of the data structure (animations, materials, light sources, cameras, textures, vertex components).
The components to be removed are specified in a separate configuration option, AI_CONFIG_PP_RVC_FLAGS. This is quite useful if you don't need all parts of the output structure. Especially vertex colors are rarely used today...calling this step to remove unrequired stuff from the pipeline as early as possible results in an increased performance and a better optimized output data structure.
This step is also useful if you want to force Assimp to recompute normals or tangents. the corresponding steps don't recompute them if they're already there (loaded from the source asset). By using this step you can make sure they are NOT there.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.GenerateNormals
member.summary:
Generates normals for all faces of all meshes. It may not be specified together with .
This is ignored if normals are already there at the time where this flag is evaluated. Model importers try to load them from the source file, so they're usually already there. Face normals are shared between all points of a single face, so a single point can have multiple normals, which in other words, forces the library to duplicate vertices in some cases. This makes senseless then.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.GenerateSmoothNormals
member.summary:
Generates smooth normals for all vertices of all meshes. It may not be specified together with .
This is ignored if normals are already there at the time where this flag is evaluated. Model importers try to load them from the source file, so they're usually already there.
The configuration option AI_CONFIG_PP_GSN_MAX_SMOOTHING_ANGLE allows you to specify an angle maximum for the normal smoothing algorithm. Normals exceeding this limit are not smoothed, resulting in a 'hard' seam between two faces. using a decent angle here (e.g. 80 degrees) results in a very good visual appearance.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.SplitLargeMeshes
member.summary:
Splits large meshes into smaller submeshes.
This is useful for realtime rendering where the number of triangles which can be maximally processed in a single draw call is usually limited by the video driver/hardware. The maximum vertex buffer is usually limited, too. Both requirements can be met with this step: you may specify both a triangle and a vertex limit for a single mesh.
The split limits can be set through the AI_CONFIG_PP_SLM_VERTEX_LIMIT and AI_CONFIG_PP_SLM_TRIANGLE_LIMIT config settings. The default values are 1,000,000.
Warning: This can be a time consuming task.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.PreTransformVertices
member.summary:
Removes the node graph and "bakes" (pre-transforms) all vertices with the local transformation matrices of their nodes. The output scene does still contain nodes, however, there is only a root node with children, each one referencing only one mesh. Each mesh referencing one material. For rendering, you can simply render all meshes in order, you don't need to pay attention to local transformations and the node hierarchy.
Warning: Animations are removed during this step.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.LimitBoneWeights
member.summary:
Limits the number of bones simultaneously affecting a single vertex to a maximum value.
If any vertex is affected by more than that number of bones, the least important vertex weights are removed and the remaining vertex weights are re-normalized so that the weights still sum up to 1.
The default bone weight limit is 4 and uses the AI_LMW_MAX_WEIGHTS config. If you intend to perform the skinning in hardware, this post processing step might be of interest for you.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.ValidateDataStructure
member.summary:
Validates the imported scene data structure.
This makes sure that all indices are valid, all animations and bones are linked correctly, all material references are correct, etc.
It is recommended to capture Assimp's log output if you use this flag, so you can easily find out what's actually wrong if a file fails the validation. The validator is quite rude and will find *all* inconsistencies in the data structure. There are two types of failures:
Error: There's something wrong with the imported data. Further postprocessing is not possible and the data is not usable at all. The import fails.
Warning: There are some minor issues (e.g. 1000000 animation keyframes with the same time), but further postprocessing and use of the data structure is still safe. Warning details are written to the log file.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.ImproveCacheLocality
member.summary:
Re-orders triangles for better vertex cache locality.
This step tries to improve the ACMR (average post-transform vertex cache miss ratio) for all meshes. The implementation runs in O(n) time and is roughly based on the 'tipsify' algorithm.
If you intend to render huge models in hardware, this step might be of interest for you. The AI_CONFIG_PP_ICL_PTCACHE_SIZE config setting can be used to fine tune the cache optimization.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.RemoveRedundantMaterials
member.summary:
Searches for redundant/unreferenced materials and removes them.
This is especially useful in combination with the PreTransformVertices and OptimizeMeshes flags. Both join small meshes with equal characteristics, but they can't do their work if two meshes have different materials. Because several material settings are always lost during Assimp's import filders and because many exporters don't check for redundant materials, huge models often have materials which are defined several times with exactly the same settings.
Several material settings not contributing to the final appearance of a surface are ignored in all comparisons ... the material name is one of them. So, if you're passing additional information through the content pipeline (probably using *magic* material names), don't specify this flag. Alternatively, take a look at the AI_CONFIG_PP_RRM_EXCLUDE_LIST setting.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.FixInFacingNormals
member.summary:
This step tries to determine which meshes have normal vectors that are facing inwards.
The algorithm is simple but effective:
The bounding box of all vertices and their normals are compared against the volume of the bounding box of all vertices without their normals. This works well for most objects, problems might occur with planar surfaces. However, the step tries to filter such cases. The step inverts all in-facing normals. Generally, it is recommended to enable this step, although the result is not always correct.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.SortByPrimitiveType
member.summary:
This step splits meshes with more than one primitive type in homogeneous submeshes.
This step is executed after triangulation and after it returns, just one bit is set in aiMesh:mPrimitiveTypes. This is especially useful for real-time rendering where point and line primitives are often ignored or rendered separately.
You can use AI_CONFIG_PP_SBP_REMOVE option to specify which primitive types you need. This can be used to easily exclude lines and points, which are rarely used, from the import.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.FindDegenerates
member.summary:
This step searches all meshes for degenerated primitives and converts them to proper lines or points. A face is 'degenerated' if one or more of its points are identical.
To have degenerated primitives removed, specify the flag try one of the following procedures:
To support lines and points: Set the AI_CONFIG_PP_FD_REMOVE option to one. This will cause the step to remove degenerated triangles as soon as they are detected. They won't pass any further pipeline steps.
If you don't support lines and points: Specify flag, which will move line and point primitives to separate meshes. Then set the AI_CONFIG_PP_SBP_REMOVE option to and to cause step to reject point and line meshes from the scene.
This step also removes very small triangles with a surface area smaller than 10^-6. If you rely on having these small triangles, or notice holes in your model, set the property to false.
Degenerated polygons are not necessarily evil and that's why they are not removed by default. There are several file formats which do not support lines or points where exporters bypass the format specification and write them as degenerated triangles instead.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.FindInvalidData
member.summary:
This step searches all meshes for invalid data, such as zeroed normal vectors or invalid UV coordinates and removes or fixes them. This is intended to get rid of some common exporter rrors.
This is especially useful for normals. If they are invalid, and the step recognizes this, they will be removed and can later be recomputed, e.g. by the GenerateSmoothNormals flag. The step will also remove meshes that are infinitely small and reduce animation tracks consisting of hundreds of redundant keys to a single key. The AI_CONFIG_PP_FID_ANIM_ACCURACY config property decides the accuracy of the check for duplicate animation tracks.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.GenerateUVCoords
member.summary:
This step converts non-UV mappings (such as spherical or cylindrical mapping) to proper texture coordinate channels.
Most applications will support UV mapping only, so you will probably want to specify this step in every case. Note that Assimp is not always able to match the original mapping implementation of the 3D app which produced a model perfectly. It's always better to let the father app compute the UV channels, at least 3DS max, maya, blender, lightwave, modo, .... are able to achieve this.
If this step is not requested, you'll need to process the MATKEY_MAPPING material property in order to display all assets properly.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.TransformUVCoords
member.summary:
Applies per-texture UV transformations and bakes them to stand-alone vtexture coordinate channels.
UV Transformations are specified per-texture - see the MATKEY_UVTRANSFORM material key for more information. This step processes all textures with transformed input UV coordinates and generates new (pretransformed) UV channel transformations, so you will probably want to specify this step.
UV transformations are usually implemented in realtime apps by transforming texture coordinates in a vertex shader stage with a 3x3 (homogenous) transformation matrix.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.FindInstances
member.summary:
Searches for duplicated meshes and replaces them with a reference to the first mesh.
This is time consuming, so don't use it if you have no time. Its main purpose is to work around the limitation with some file formats that don't support instanced meshes, so exporters duplicate meshes.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.OptimizeMeshes
member.summary:
Attempts to reduce the number of meshes (and draw calls).
This is recommended to be used together with and is fully compatible with both and .

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.OptimizeGraph
member.summary:
Optimizes scene hierarchy. Nodes with no animations, bones, lights, or cameras assigned are collapsed and joined.
Node names can be lost during this step, you can specify names of nodes that should'nt be touched or modified with AI_CONFIG_PP_OG_EXCLUDE_LIST.
Use this flag with caution. Most simple files will be collapsed to a single node, complex hierarchies are usually completely lost. That's not the right choice for editor environments, but probably a very effective optimization if you just want to get the model data, convert it to your own format and render it as fast as possible.
This flag is designed to be used with for best results.
Scenes with thousands of extremely small meshes packed in deeply nested nodes exist for almost all file formats. Usage of this and usually fixes them all and makes them renderable.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.FlipUVs
member.summary: Flips all UV coordinates along the y-axis and adjusts material settings/bitangents accordingly.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.FlipWindingOrder
member.summary: Flips face winding order from CCW (default) to CW.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.SplitByBoneCount
member.summary: Splits meshes with many bones into submeshes so that each submesh has fewer or as many bones as a given limit.

summary.para: Removes bones losslessly or according to some threshold. In some cases (e.g. formats that require it) exporters are faced to assign dummy bone weights to otherwise static meshes assigned to animated meshes. Full, weight-based skinning is expensive while animating nodes is extremely cheap, so this step is offered to clean up the data in that regard.
Usage of the configuration AI_CONFIG_PP_DB_THRESHOLD to control the threshold and AI_CONFIG_PP_DB_ALL_OR_NONE if you want bones removed if and only if all bones within the scene qualify for removal.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.GlobalScale
member.summary: This step will perform a global scale of the model. Some importers provide a mechanism to define a scaling unit for the model, which this processing step can utilize. Use AI_CONFIG_GLOBAL_SCALE_FACTOR_KEY to setup the global scaling factor.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.EmbedTextures
member.summary: A post processting step to embed textures. This will remove external data dependencies for textures. If a texture's file does not exist at the specified path (due, for instance, to an absolute path generate on another system), it will check if a file with the same name exists at the root folder of the imported model, and if so, embeds that.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.ForceGenerateNormals
member.summary: If the step to generate normals is set, it will not run if normals already exist. This flag will force that step to run even if normals are present.

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.DropNormals
member.summary: Drops normals for all faces of all meshes. This is ignored if no normals are present. Face normals are shared between all points of a single face, so a single point can have multiple normals, which forces the library to duplicate vertices in some cases. is *senseless* then. This process gives sense back to .

member.name: F:Assimp.PostProcessSteps.GenerateBoundingBoxes
member.summary: Generate bounding boxes for each mesh.

member.summary: Removes all materials. One default material will be generated.

member.name: T:Assimp.PrimitiveType
member.summary: Enumerates geometric primitive types.

member.name: F:Assimp.PrimitiveType.Point
member.summary: Point primitive. This is just a single vertex in the virtual world. A face has one index for such a primitive.

member.name: F:Assimp.PrimitiveType.Line
member.summary: Line primitive. This is a line defined through a start and an end position. A face contains exactly two indices for such a primitive.

member.name: F:Assimp.PrimitiveType.Triangle
member.summary: Triangle primitive, consisting of three indices.

member.name: F:Assimp.PrimitiveType.Polygon
member.summary: A n-Gon that has more than three edges (thus is not a triangle).

member.name: T:Assimp.AnimationBehaviour
member.summary: Defines an animation channel behaves outside the defined time range. This corresponds to the prestate and poststates of the animation node.

member.name: F:Assimp.AnimationBehaviour.Default
member.summary: The value from the default node transformation is taken.

member.name: F:Assimp.AnimationBehaviour.Constant
member.summary: The nearest key value is used without interpolation.

member.name: F:Assimp.AnimationBehaviour.Linear
member.summary: The value of the nearest two keys is linearly extrapolated for the current time value.

member.name: F:Assimp.AnimationBehaviour.Repeat
member.summary: The animation is repeated. If the animation key goes from n to m and the current time is t, use the value at (t - n ) % (|m-n|).

member.name: T:Assimp.LightSourceType
member.summary: Enumerates all supported light sources.

member.name: F:Assimp.LightSourceType.Undefined
member.summary: Unknown light.

member.name: F:Assimp.LightSourceType.Directional
member.summary: Directional light source that has a well-defined direction but is infinitely far away, e.g. the sun.

member.name: F:Assimp.LightSourceType.Point
member.summary: Point light source that has a well-defined position in space but is omni-directional, e.g. a light bulb.

member.name: F:Assimp.LightSourceType.Spot
member.summary: Spot light source emits light from a position in space, in a certain direction that is limited by an angle, like a cone.

member.name: F:Assimp.LightSourceType.Ambient
member.summary: Generic light level of the world, including the bounces of all other light sources. Typically, there's at most one ambient light in a scene and is usually just a constant color. This light does not have a valid position, direction, or other properties - just the color.

member.name: F:Assimp.LightSourceType.Area
member.summary: An area light is a rectangle with a predefined size that uniformly emits light from one of its sides. The position is center of the rectangle and the direction is its normal vector.

member.name: T:Assimp.BlendMode
member.summary:
Defines alpha blending flags, how the final color value of a pixel is computed, based on the following equation:
sourceColor * sourceBlend + destColor * destBlend
Where the destColor is the previous color in the frame buffer and sourceColor is the material color before the transparency calculation. This corresponds to the AI_MATKEY_BLEND_FUNC property.

member.name: F:Assimp.BlendMode.Default
member.summary: Default blending: sourceColor * sourceAlpha + destColor * (1 - sourceAlpha)

member.name: F:Assimp.BlendMode.Additive
member.summary: Additive blending: sourcecolor * 1 + destColor * 1.

member.name: T:Assimp.ShadingMode
member.summary:
Defines all shading models supported by the library.
The list of shading modes has been taken from Blender. See Blender documentation for more information.

member.name: F:Assimp.ShadingMode.None
member.summary: No shading mode defined.

member.name: F:Assimp.ShadingMode.Flat
member.summary: Flat shading. Shading is done on a per-face basis and is diffuse only. Also known as 'faceted shading'.

member.name: F:Assimp.ShadingMode.Gouraud
member.summary: Simple Gouraud shading.

member.name: F:Assimp.ShadingMode.Phong
member.summary: Phong Shading.

member.name: F:Assimp.ShadingMode.Blinn
member.summary: Phong-Blinn Shading.

member.name: F:Assimp.ShadingMode.Toon
member.summary: Toon-shading, also known as a 'comic' shader.

member.name: F:Assimp.ShadingMode.OrenNayar
member.summary: OrenNayer shading model. Extension to standard Lambertian shading, taking the roughness of the material into account.

member.name: F:Assimp.ShadingMode.Minnaert
member.summary: Minnaert shading model. Extension to standard Lambertian shading, taking the "darkness" of the material into account.

member.name: F:Assimp.ShadingMode.CookTorrance
member.summary: CookTorrance shading model. Special shader for metallic surfaces.

member.name: F:Assimp.ShadingMode.NoShading
member.summary: No shading at all. Constant light influence of 1.0.

member.name: F:Assimp.ShadingMode.Fresnel
member.summary: Fresnel shading.

member.name: T:Assimp.TextureFlags
member.summary: Defines some mixed flags for a particular texture. This corresponds to the AI_MAT_KEY_TEXFLAGS property.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureFlags.Invert
member.summary: The texture's color values have to be inverted (componentwise 1-n).

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureFlags.UseAlpha
member.summary: Explicit request to the application to process the alpha channel of the texture. This is mutually exclusive with . These flags are set if the library can say for sure that the alpha channel is used/is not used. If the model format does not define this, iti s left to the application to decide whether the texture alpha channel - if any - is evaluated or not.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureFlags.IgnoreAlpha
member.summary: Explicit request to the application to ignore the alpha channel of the texture. This is mutually exclusive with .

member.name: T:Assimp.TextureWrapMode
member.summary: Defines how UV coordinates outside the [0..1] range are handled. Commonly referred to as the 'wrapping mode'

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureWrapMode.Wrap
member.summary: A texture coordinate u|v is translated to u % 1| v % 1.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureWrapMode.Clamp
member.summary: Texture coordinates outside [0...1] are clamped to the nearest valid value.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureWrapMode.Mirror
member.summary: A texture coordinate u|v becomes u1|v1 if (u - (u % 1)) % 2 is zero and 1 - (u % 1) | 1 - (v % 1) otherwise.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureWrapMode.Decal
member.summary: If the texture coordinates for a pixel are outside [0...1] the texture is not applied to that pixel.

member.name: T:Assimp.TextureMapping
member.summary:
Defines how texture coordinates are generated
Real-time applications typically require full UV coordinates. So the use of step is highly recommended. It generates proper UV channels for non-UV mapped objects, as long as an accurate description of how the mapping should look like is given.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureMapping.FromUV
member.summary:
Coordinates are taken from the an existing UV channel.
The AI_MATKEY_UVWSRC key specifies from the UV channel the texture coordinates are to be taken from since meshes can have more than one UV channel.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureMapping.Sphere
member.summary: Spherical mapping

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureMapping.Cylinder
member.summary: Cylinder mapping

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureMapping.Box
member.summary: Cubic mapping

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureMapping.Plane
member.summary: Planar mapping

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureMapping.Unknown
member.summary: Unknown mapping that is not recognied.

member.name: T:Assimp.TextureOperation
member.summary:
Defines how the Nth texture of a specific type is combined with the result of all previous layers.
Example (left: key, right: value):
DiffColor0 - gray DiffTextureOp0 - TextureOperation.Multiply DiffTexture0 - tex1.png DiffTextureOp0 - TextureOperation.Add DiffTexture1 - tex2.png
Written as an equation, the final diffuse term for a specific pixel would be:
diffFinal = DiffColor0 * sampleTex(DiffTexture0, UV0) + sampleTex(DiffTexture1, UV0) * diffContrib;

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureOperation.Multiply
member.summary: T = T1 * T2

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureOperation.Add
member.summary: T = T1 + T2

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureOperation.Subtract
member.summary: T = T1 - T2

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureOperation.Divide
member.summary: T = T1 / T2

member.name: T:Assimp.TextureType
member.summary: Defines the purpose of a texture.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.None
member.summary: No texture, but the value can be used as a 'texture semantic'.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Diffuse
member.summary: A diffuse texture that is combined with the result of the diffuse lighting equation.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Specular
member.summary: A specular texture that is combined with the result of the specular lighting equation.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Ambient
member.summary: An ambient texture that is combined with the ambient lighting equation.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Emissive
member.summary: An emissive texture that is added to the result of the lighting calculation. It is not influenced by incoming light, instead it represents the light that the object is naturally emitting.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Height
member.summary: A height map texture. by convention, higher gray-scale values stand for higher elevations from some base height.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Normals
member.summary: A tangent-space normal map. There are several conventions for normal maps and Assimp does (intentionally) not distinguish here.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Shininess
member.summary: A texture that defines the glossiness of the material. This is the exponent of the specular (phong) lighting equation. Usually there is a conversion function defined to map the linear color values in the texture to a suitable exponent.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Opacity
member.summary: The texture defines per-pixel opacity. usually 'white' means opaque and 'black' means 'transparency. Or quite the opposite.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Displacement
member.summary: A displacement texture. The exact purpose and format is application-dependent. Higher color values stand for higher vertex displacements.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Lightmap
member.summary: A lightmap texture (aka Ambient occlusion). Both 'lightmaps' and dedicated 'ambient occlusion maps' are covered by this material property. The texture contains a scaling value for the final color value of a pixel. Its intensity is not affected by incoming light.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Reflection
member.summary: A reflection texture. Contains the color of a perfect mirror reflection. This is rarely used, almost never for real-time applications.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.BaseColor
member.summary: PBR texture property. Diffuse/albedo map containing base color regardless of the object surface type.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.NormalCamera
member.summary: PBR texture property. This is not documented in assimp native, but is a normal map in a PBR workflow.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.EmissionColor
member.summary: PBR texture property. Emissive color map, similar to .

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Metalness
member.summary: PBR texture property. Describes how reflective the object surface is.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Roughness
member.summary: PBR texture property. Describes how rough or smooth the object surface is.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.AmbientOcclusion
member.summary: Dedicated ambient occlusion map, some older formats may set this as a texture.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Unknown
member.summary: An unknown texture that does not mention any of the defined texture type definitions. It is still imported, but is excluded from any further postprocessing.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Sheen
member.summary: Generally used to simulate textiles that are covered in a layer of microfibers, e.g. velvet.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Clearcoat
member.summary: Simulates a layer of 'polish' or 'lacquer' layered on top of a PBR substrate.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Transmission
member.summary: Simulates transmission through the surface. May include further information such as wall thickness.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.MayaBase
member.summary: Maya material declaration for a base color texture.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.MayaSpecular
member.summary: Maya material declaration for a specular texture.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.MayaSpecularColor
member.summary: Maya material declaration for a specular color texture.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.MayaSpecularRoughness
member.summary: Maya material declaration for a specular roughness texture.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.Anisotropy
member.summary: Simulates a surface with directional properties.

member.name: F:Assimp.TextureType.GltfMetallicRoughness
member.summary: Textures for metalness and roughness properties packed together in a single texture. Its green channel contains roughness values and its blue channel contains metalness values.

member.name: T:Assimp.SceneFlags
member.summary: Defines the state of the imported scene data structure.

member.name: F:Assimp.SceneFlags.None
member.summary: Default state of the scene, it imported successfully.

member.name: F:Assimp.SceneFlags.Incomplete
member.summary: Specifies that the scene data structure that was imported is not complete. This flag bypasses some internal validations and allows the import of animation skeletons, material libaries, or camera animation paths using Assimp. Most applications won't support such data.

member.name: F:Assimp.SceneFlags.Validated
member.summary: This flag is set by the post process step if validation is successful. In a validated scene you can be sure that any cross references in the data structure (e.g. vertex indices) are valid.

member.name: F:Assimp.SceneFlags.ValidationWarning
member.summary: This flag is set by the post process step if validation is successful, but some issues have been found. This can for example mean that a texture that does not exist is referenced by a material or that the bone weights for a vertex do not sum to 1.0. In most cases you should still be able to use the import. This flag can be useful for applications which do not capture Assimp's log output.

member.name: F:Assimp.SceneFlags.NonVerboseFormat
member.summary: This flag is set by the post process step. It indicates that the vertices of the output mesh are not in the internal verbose format anymore. In the verbose format, all vertices are unique where no vertex is ever referenced by more than one face.

member.name: F:Assimp.SceneFlags.Terrain
member.summary:
Denotes the scene is pure height-map terrain data. Pure terrains usually consist of quads, sometimes triangles, in a regular grid. The x,y coordinates of all vertex positions refer to the x,y coordinates on the terrain height map, the z-axis stores the elevation at a specific point.
TER (Terragen) and HMP (3D Game Studio) are height map formats.

member.name: F:Assimp.SceneFlags.AllowShared
member.summary: Specifies that the scene data can be shared between structures. For example: one vertex in a few faces. This differs from as that has internal meanings about postprocessing steps.

member.name: T:Assimp.ExportDataBlob
member.summary: Describes a blob of exported scene data. Blobs can be nested - each blob may reference another blob, which in turn can reference another and so on. This is used to allow exporters to write more than one output for a given scene, such as material files. Existence of such files depends on the format.
member.remarks:
The stream representation of an ExportDataBlob is as follows:
String: Name of the Blob int: Length of Binary Data byte[]: Binary Data bool: If has next data blob String: Name of nested blob int: Length of nested blob binary data byte[]: Nested blob binary data bool: If nested blob has next data blob ....

member.name: P:Assimp.ExportDataBlob.Name
member.summary: Gets the name of the blob. The first and primary blob always has an empty string for a name. Auxillary files that are nested will have names.

member.summary: Get the blob data.

member.name: P:Assimp.ExportDataBlob.NextBlob
member.summary: Gets the next data blob.

member.name: P:Assimp.ExportDataBlob.HasData
member.summary: Gets if the blob data is valid.

member.name: T:Assimp.Face
member.summary:
A single face in a mesh, referring to multiple vertices. This can be a triangle if the index count is equal to three, or a polygon if the count is greater than three.
Since multiple primitive types can be contained in a single mesh, this approach allows you to better examine how the mesh is constructed. If you use the post process step flag during import, then each mesh will be homogenous where primitive type is concerned.

member.summary: Gets if the face has faces (should always be true).

member.summary: Gets or sets the indices that refer to positions of vertex data in the mesh's vertex arrays.

member.name: T:Assimp.FileIOSystem
member.summary: Simple implementation of an IOSystem that searches for files on the disk. This implementation can be given a number of search directories that it will attempt to locate the file in first, before using the file path given by Assimp. That way, you can load models that have files distributed in a number of other directories besides the root model's.

member.name: T:Assimp.Light
member.summary:
Describes a light source in the scene. Assimp supports multiple light sources including spot, point, and directional lights. All are defined by a single structure and distinguished by their parameters. Lights have corresponding nodes in the scenegraph.
Some file formats such as 3DS and ASE export a "target point", e.g. the point a spot light is looking at (it can even be animated). Assimp writes the target point as a subnode of a spotlight's main node called "spotName.Target". However, this is just additional information then, the transform tracks of the main node make the spot light already point in the right direction.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the light source. This corresponds to a node present in the scenegraph.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.LightType
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of light source. This should never be undefined.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.AngleInnerCone
member.summary: Gets or sets the inner angle of a spot light's light cone. The spot light has maximum influence on objects inside this angle. The angle is given in radians, it is 2PI for point lights and defined for directional lights.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.AngleOuterCone
member.summary: Gets or sets the outer angle of a spot light's light cone. The spot light does not affect objects outside this angle. The angle is given in radians. It is 2PI for point lights and undefined for directional lights. The outer angle must be greater than or equal to the inner angle.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.AttenuationConstant
member.summary:
Gets or sets the constant light attenuation factor. The intensity of the light source at a given distance 'd' from the light position is Atten = 1 / (att0 + att1 * d + att2 * d*d).
This member corresponds to the att0 variable in the equation and is undefined for directional lights.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.AttenuationLinear
member.summary:
Gets or sets the linear light attenuation factor. The intensity of the light source at a given distance 'd' from the light position is Atten = 1 / (att0 + att1 * d + att2 * d*d)
This member corresponds to the att1 variable in the equation and is undefined for directional lights.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.AttenuationQuadratic
member.summary:
Gets or sets the quadratic light attenuation factor. The intensity of the light source at a given distance 'd' from the light position is Atten = 1 / (att0 + att1 * d + att2 * d*d).
This member corresponds to the att2 variable in the equation and is undefined for directional lights.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.Position
member.summary: Gets or sets the position of the light source in space, relative to the transformation of the node corresponding to the light. This is undefined for directional lights.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.Direction
member.summary: Gets or sets the direction of the light source in space, relative to the transformation of the node corresponding to the light. This is undefined for point lights.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.Up
member.summary: Gets or sets the up vector of the light source in space, relative to the transformation of the node corresponding to the light. This is undefined for point lights.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.ColorDiffuse
member.summary: Gets or sets the diffuse color of the light source. The diffuse light color is multiplied with the diffuse material color to obtain the final color that contributes to the diffuse shading term.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.ColorSpecular
member.summary: Gets or sets the specular color of the light source. The specular light color is multiplied with the specular material color to obtain the final color that contributes to the specular shading term.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.ColorAmbient
member.summary: Gets or sets the ambient color of the light source. The ambient light color is multiplied with the ambient material color to obtain the final color that contributes to the ambient shading term.

member.name: P:Assimp.Light.AreaSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the Width (X) and Height (Y) of the area that represents an light.

member.name: T:Assimp.Material
member.summary: A material contains all the information that describes how to render a mesh. E.g. textures, colors, and render states. Internally all this information is stored as key-value pair properties. The class contains many convienence methods and properties for accessing non-texture/texture properties without having to know the Assimp material key names. Not all properties may be present, and if they aren't a default value will be returned.

member.summary: Checks if the material has a two-sided property.

member.name: P:Assimp.Material.BlendMode

member.name: P:Assimp.Material.TransparencyFactor
member.summary: Gets the transparency factor. This is used to make a surface more or less opaque (0 = opaque, 1 = transparent). Default value is 0.0f.

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.#ctor

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.CreateFullyQualifiedName(System.String,Assimp.TextureType,System.Int32)
member.summary: Helper method to construct a fully qualified name from the input parameters. All the input parameters are combined into the fully qualified name: {baseName},{texType},{texIndex}. E.g. "$clr.diffuse,0,0" or "$tex.file,1,0". This is the name that is used as the material dictionary key.
member.param: Key basename, this must not be null or empty
Texture type; non-texture properties should leave this
Texture index; non-texture properties should leave this zero.
member.returns: The fully qualified name

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.GetNonTextureProperty(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the non-texture properties contained in this Material. The name should be the "base name", as in it should not contain texture type/texture index information. E.g. "$clr.diffuse" rather than "$clr.diffuse,0,0". The extra data will be filled in automatically.
member.returns: The material property, if it exists

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.GetProperty(System.String,Assimp.TextureType,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the material property. All the input parameters are combined into the fully qualified name: {baseName},{texType},{texIndex}. E.g. "$clr.diffuse,0,0" or "$tex.file,1,0".
member.param: Texture type; non-texture properties should leave this
Texture index; non-texture properties should leave this zero.
member.returns: The material property, if it exists

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.GetProperty(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the material property by its fully qualified name. The format is: {baseName},{texType},{texIndex}. E.g. "$clr.diffuse,0,0" or "$tex.file,1,0".
member.param: Fully qualified name of the property
member.returns: The material property, if it exists

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.HasNonTextureProperty(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if the material has the specified non-texture property. The name should be the "base name", as in it should not contain texture type/texture index information. E.g. "$clr.diffuse" rather than "$clr.diffuse,0,0". The extra data will be filled in automatically.
member.returns: True if the property exists, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.HasProperty(System.String,Assimp.TextureType,System.Int32)
member.summary: Checks if the material has the specified property. All the input parameters are combined into the fully qualified name: {baseName},{texType},{texIndex}. E.g. "$clr.diffuse,0,0" or "$tex.file,1,0".
member.param: Texture type; non-texture properties should leave this
Texture index; non-texture properties should leave this zero.
member.returns: True if the property exists, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.HasProperty(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if the material has the specified property by looking up its fully qualified name. The format is: {baseName},{texType},{texIndex}. E.g. "$clr.diffuse,0,0" or "$tex.file,1,0".
member.param: Fully qualified name of the property
member.returns: True if the property exists, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.AddProperty(Assimp.MaterialProperty)
member.summary: Adds a property to this material.
member.returns: True if the property was successfully added, false otherwise (e.g. null or key already present).

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.RemoveNonTextureProperty(System.String)
member.summary: Removes a non-texture property from the material.

member.summary: Removes a property from the material.
member.returns: True if the property was removed, false otherwise

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.RemoveProperty(System.String)
member.summary: Removes a property from the material.
member.param: Fully qualified name of the property ({basename},{texType},{texIndex})
member.returns: True if the property was removed, false otherwise

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.AddMaterialTexture(Assimp.TextureSlot@)
member.summary: Adds a texture to the material - this bulk creates a property for each field. This will either create properties or overwrite existing properties. If the texture has no file path, nothing is added.
member.returns: True if the texture properties were added or modified

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.AddMaterialTexture(Assimp.TextureSlot@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds a texture to the material - this bulk creates a property for each field. This will either create properties or overwrite existing properties. If the texture has no file path, nothing is added.
member.param: True to only set the texture's file path, false otherwise
member.returns: True if the texture properties were added or modified

member.name: M:Assimp.Material.RemoveMaterialTexture(Assimp.TextureSlot@)
member.summary: Removes a texture from the material - this bulk removes a property for each field. If the texture has no file path, nothing is removed
member.returns: True if the texture was removed, false otherwise.

member.name: T:Assimp.MaterialProperty
member.summary: A key-value pairing that represents some material property.

member.name: P:Assimp.MaterialProperty.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the property key name. E.g. $tex.file. This corresponds to the "AiMatKeys" base name constants.

member.summary: Gets or sets the type of property.

member.summary: Gets the raw byte data count.

member.summary: Checks if the property has data.

member.summary: Gets the raw byte data. To modify/read this data, see the Get/SetXXXValue methods.

member.name: P:Assimp.MaterialProperty.TextureType
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture type semantic, for non-texture properties this is always .

member.name: P:Assimp.MaterialProperty.TextureIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture index, for non-texture properties this is always zero.

member.name: P:Assimp.MaterialProperty.FullyQualifiedName
member.summary: Gets the property's fully qualified name. Format: "{base name},{texture type semantic},{texture index}". E.g. "$clr.diffuse,0,0". This is the key that is used to index the property in the material property map.

member.name: T:Assimp.Matrix3x3
member.summary: Represents a 3x3 matrix. Assimp docs say their matrices are always row-major, and it looks like they're only describing the memory layout. Matrices are treated as column vectors however (X base in the first column, Y base the second, and Z base the third)
member.param: Value at row 1, column 1 of the matrix.
Value at row 1, column 2 of the matrix.
Value at row 1, column 3 of the matrix.
Value at row 2, column 1 of the matrix.
Value at row 2, column 2 of the matrix.
Value at row 2, column 3 of the matrix.
Value at row 3, column 1 of the matrix.
Value at row 3, column 2 of the matrix.
Value at row 3, column 3 of the matrix.

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Represents a 3x3 matrix. Assimp docs say their matrices are always row-major, and it looks like they're only describing the memory layout. Matrices are treated as column vectors however (X base in the first column, Y base the second, and Z base the third)
member.param: Value at row 1, column 1 of the matrix.
Value at row 1, column 2 of the matrix.
Value at row 1, column 3 of the matrix.
Value at row 2, column 1 of the matrix.
Value at row 2, column 2 of the matrix.
Value at row 2, column 3 of the matrix.
Value at row 3, column 1 of the matrix.
Value at row 3, column 2 of the matrix.
Value at row 3, column 3 of the matrix.

member.summary: Value at row 1, column 1 of the matrix.

member.summary: Value at row 1, column 2 of the matrix.

member.name: P:Assimp.Matrix3x3.A3
member.summary: Value at row 1, column 3 of the matrix.

member.summary: Value at row 2, column 1 of the matrix.

member.summary: Value at row 2, column 2 of the matrix.

member.name: P:Assimp.Matrix3x3.B3
member.summary: Value at row 2, column 3 of the matrix.

member.summary: Value at row 3, column 1 of the matrix.

member.summary: Value at row 3, column 2 of the matrix.

member.name: P:Assimp.Matrix3x3.C3
member.summary: Value at row 3, column 3 of the matrix.

member.name: P:Assimp.Matrix3x3.Identity
member.summary: Gets the identity matrix.

member.summary: Gets if this matrix is an identity matrix.

member.name: P:Assimp.Matrix3x3.Item(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets or sets the value at the specific one-based row, column index. E.g. i = 1, j = 2 gets the value in row 1, column 2 (MA2). Indices out of range return a value of zero.
member.returns: Matrix value

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.#ctor(System.Numerics.Matrix4x4)
member.summary: Constructs a new Matrix3x3.
member.param: A 4x4 matrix to construct from, only taking the rotation/scaling part.

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.Transpose
member.summary: Transposes this matrix (rows become columns, vice versa).

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.Inverse
member.summary: Inverts the matrix. If the matrix is *not* invertible all elements are set to .

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.Determinant
member.summary: Compute the determinant of this matrix.
member.returns: The determinant

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.FromEulerAnglesXYZ(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates a rotation matrix from a set of euler angles.
member.param: Rotation angle about the x-axis, in radians.
Rotation angle about the y-axis, in radians.
Rotation angle about the z-axis, in radians.
member.returns: The rotation matrix

member.summary: Creates a rotation matrix from a set of euler angles.
member.param: Vector containing the rotation angles about the x, y, z axes, in radians.
member.returns: The rotation matrix

member.summary: Creates a rotation matrix for a rotation about the x-axis.
member.returns: The rotation matrix

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.FromRotationY(System.Single)
member.summary: Creates a rotation matrix for a rotation about the y-axis.
member.returns: The rotation matrix

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.FromRotationZ(System.Single)
member.summary: Creates a rotation matrix for a rotation about the z-axis.
member.returns: The rotation matrix

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.FromAngleAxis(System.Single,System.Numerics.Vector3)
member.summary: Creates a rotation matrix for a rotation about an arbitrary axis.
member.param: Rotation axis, which should be a normalized vector.
member.returns: The rotation matrix

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.FromScaling(System.Numerics.Vector3)
member.summary: Creates a scaling matrix.
member.returns: The scaling vector

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.FromToMatrix(System.Numerics.Vector3,System.Numerics.Vector3)
member.summary:
Creates a rotation matrix that rotates a vector called "from" into another vector called "to". Based on an algorithm by Tomas Moller and John Hudges:
"Efficiently Building a Matrix to Rotate One Vector to Another" Journal of Graphics Tools, 4(4):1-4, 1999
member.returns: Rotation matrix to rotate from the start to end.

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.Transform(System.Numerics.Vector3)
member.summary: Performs matrix-vector multiplication identical to the way Assimp does it.
member.returns: Transformed vector

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.op_Multiply(Assimp.Matrix3x3,Assimp.Matrix3x3)
member.summary: Performs matrix multiplication.Multiplication order is B x A. That way, SRT concatenations are left to right.
member.returns: Multiplied matrix

member.name: M:Assimp.Matrix3x3.op_Implicit(System.Numerics.Matrix4x4)~Assimp.Matrix3x3
member.summary: Implicit conversion from a 4x4 matrix to a 3x3 matrix.
member.returns: 3x3 matrix

member.summary: Implicit conversion from a 3x3 matrix to a 4x4 matrix.
